security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing templates and guidance for security requirement extraction. Python code examples in SKILL.md are documentation templates only, not executable code. All 47 static findings are false positives: URLs are documentation links, backticks are markdown code blocks, and security terminology (C2, crypto, reconnaissance, SAM) appears in legitimate compliance and threat modeling context. No actual code execution, network calls, or credential access occurs.

content.value_statement: Security threats are hard to turn into clear requirements. This skill converts threats into testable requirements, user stories, and compliance mappings. Use it when translating threat models into actionable security controls.
actual_capabilities: Extracts requirements from STRIDE threat inputs
Formats requirements as user stories with acceptance criteria
Builds threat to requirement traceability matrices
limitations: Requires clear threat inputs and categories
Provides templates, not runnable tools or automation
Does not perform threat modeling itself
Compliance mapping is limited to included frameworks

use_cases.title: Threat to requirement mapping
use_cases.description: Convert STRIDE threat lists into prioritized security requirements with rationale.

use_cases.title: Security user stories
use_cases.description: Produce user stories and acceptance criteria for security backlog planning.

use_cases.title: Control traceability
use_cases.description: Map requirements to PCI DSS, HIPAA, GDPR, and OWASP controls.

prompt_templates.title: Basic extraction
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert this threat into security requirements with acceptance criteria and test cases: [threat details].

prompt_templates.title: STRIDE batch
prompt_templates.prompt: Extract security requirements for these STRIDE threats and group by domain: [list of threats].

prompt_templates.title: User story focus
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate security user stories with priority and acceptance criteria for these threats: [threats].

prompt_templates.title: Compliance mapping
prompt_templates.prompt: Map these requirements to PCI DSS and OWASP controls, and note gaps: [requirements].

output_examples.input: Create requirements from a spoofing threat targeting login
output: SR-001: Authenticate users before access to login
Acceptance criteria: MFA for sensitive operations, authentication failures logged
Test cases: Unauthenticated access denied, invalid credentials rejected, tokens cannot be forged

output_examples.input: Generate requirements for data tampering threats
output: SR-005: Validate all input to data store
Acceptance criteria: Data integrity verified, modification attempts trigger alerts
Test cases: Invalid input rejected, tampered data detected and rejected

best_practices: Provide clear threat descriptions with impact and likelihood ratings
Trace each requirement to a specific threat identifier
Include measurable acceptance criteria and testable conditions
anti_patterns: Omitting rationale or priority for requirements
Mapping to compliance without threat traceability

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. It provides text templates and guidance usable in these platforms.

faq.question: What are the limits of the generated requirements?
faq.answer: They depend on the quality of the input threats and categories provided.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with my tooling?
faq.answer: Yes. Export the outputs into your backlog or test management system.

faq.question: Does this skill access or store sensitive data?
faq.answer: No. It is static guidance with no code execution or data access.

faq.question: What if outputs seem too generic?
faq.answer: Add more context such as assets, actors, and business impact details.

faq.question: How does this compare to a threat modeling tool?
faq.answer: It translates threats into requirements but does not create the threat model itself.
